description:
Method for isolating mesophyll protoplasts from Arabidopsis as a system for monitoring RNA stability using transcriptional inhibitors (e.g. cordycepin) under stress treatments (e.g. high-light or hydrogen peroxide treatment).

 

Adapted from Yoo S.-D., Cho Y.-H. & Sheen J. (2007) Arabidopsis mesophyll protoplasts: a versatile cell system for transient gene expression analysis. Nature Protocols 2, 1565–1572.
before_start:
Before starting experiment, it is considered ideal to keep intended Arabidopsis plants for protoplast extraction in the dark overnight. This is so that all the starch is used up, making the isolation procedure easier (less junk in extract).

 

Prepare the following solutions:

Enzyme Solution: Make solution of 20mM MES (pH 5.7), 0.4M Mannitol and 20mM KCl. Heat solution to 70°C for 3-5min. To this add cellulose R10 (1.5%) and macerozyme R10 (0.4%). Warm solution to 55°C for 10 min (inactivates DNAse and proteases and aids solubilising enzyme). Cool to room temperature and add 10mM Ca Cl2, 1-5mM ß-mercaptoethanol (optional) and 0.1% BSA. Filter the final enzyme solution through a 0.45um syringe filter into a petri dish (enzyme solution should be made fresh, however, can be stored overnight at 4°C).

W5 Solution: 2mM MES (pH 5.7), 154mM NaCl, 125mM CaCl2 and 5mM KCl.

MMG Solution: 4mM MES (pH5.7), 0.4M Mannitol and 15mM MgCl2.

materials.reagent_name: Syringe Filtration - Aqueous Solutions, Sterile, Individual Pack, 0.45UM, 13mm, 10/Pk
BRAND® counting chamber BLAUBRAND® Neubauer improved New without clips, double ruled

manuscript_citation: Crisp P.A., Ganguly D.R., Smith A.B., Murray K.D., Estavillo G.M., Searle I., … Pogson B.J. (2017) Rapid Recovery Gene Downregulation during Excess-Light Stress and Recovery in Arabidopsis. The Plant Cell 29, 1836–1863.
guidelines:
Adapted from Yoo S.-D., Cho Y.-H. & Sheen J. (2007) Arabidopsis mesophyll protoplasts: a versatile cell system for transient gene expression analysis. Nature Protocols 2, 1565–1572.

 

Ideally, preps will be done on 3-4 week old Arabidopsis plants (before flowering). Choose well-expanded leaves (usually #5 & #7).

 

Protoplasting 80 leaves (using ~ 65 - 75 mL enzyme solution) from 3 week old plants yielded approx. 1.5 million protoplasts (diluted to 20,000/mL) from which 1.4 - 2.8 ug total RNA (of high quality) could be extracted using TRIzol.

 

Higher RNA yields were obtained using fewer leaves and more enzyme solution (40-50 leaves of 3 week old plants gave ~4 ug total RNA).
status_info: We have used this protocol to successfully measure gene expression in protoplasts under stress conditions.

components.data: Keep plants in dark overnight (the day before)
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Keep plants in dark overnight (the day before)

components.data:
Before starting experiment, it is considered ideal to keep intended Arabidopsis plants for protoplast extraction in the dark overnight. This is so that all the starch is used up, making the isolation procedure easier (less junk in extract).

 

Use 3-4 week old Arabidopsis plants (before flowering). Choose well-expanded leave (usually #5 & #7). Approx. 40 leaves (in 50ml enzyme solution) should give a yield of roughly 1, 500, 000 protoplasts (can extract almost 3ug RNA from this using TRIzol method). This is suitable for routine experiments. For larger scale: Sheen et al. suggests 100 – 150 leaves in 40 – 60ml enzyme solution yielding 107.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Before starting experiment, it is considered ideal to keep intended Arabidopsis plants for protoplast extraction in the dark overnight. This is so that all the starch is used up, making the isolation procedure easier (less junk in extract).

 

Use 3-4 week old Arabidopsis plants (before flowering). Choose well-expanded leave (usually #5 & #7). Approx. 40 leaves (in 50ml enzyme solution) should give a yield of roughly 1, 500, 000 protoplasts (can extract almost 3ug RNA from this using TRIzol method). This is suitable for routine experiments. For larger scale: Sheen et al. suggests 100 – 150 leaves in 40 – 60ml enzyme solution yielding 107.

components.data: Cut 0.5-1mm leaf strips of the leaf using a fresh sharp razor blade (on a nice cutting surface) without tissue crushing at the cutting site (i.e. try not to push down on the tissue with the blade, rather try to “glide” the blade to make the cut).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Cut 0.5-1mm leaf strips of the leaf using a fresh sharp razor blade (on a nice cutting surface) without tissue crushing at the cutting site (i.e. try not to push down on the tissue with the blade, rather try to “glide” the blade to make the cut).

components.data: Enzyme digestion of leaf material
components.name: Section

components.data: Transfer leaf cuts quickly and gently into enzyme solution and make sure leaf strips are submerged nicely.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer leaf cuts quickly and gently into enzyme solution and make sure leaf strips are submerged nicely.

components.data: Enzyme digestion of leaf material
components.name: Section

components.data: Enzyme digestion of leaf material
components.name: Section

components.data: Vacuum infiltrate 3 x 10 min.
components.name: Description

components.data: Enzyme digestion of leaf material
components.name: Section

components.data: Continue digestion, without shaking, in the dark for at least 3 hours @ room temperature (enzyme solution should turn from a light brown colour to green after gentle swirling which indicates protoplast release).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Continue digestion, without shaking, in the dark for at least 3 hours @ room temperature (enzyme solution should turn from a light brown colour to green after gentle swirling which indicates protoplast release).

components.data: Enzyme digestion of leaf material
components.name: Section

components.data: Check for release of protoplasts in solution under the microscope (after gentle swirling). Arabidopsis mesophyll protoplasts are approximately 30 - 50 µm in diameter.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Check for release of protoplasts in solution under the microscope (after gentle swirling). Arabidopsis mesophyll protoplasts are approximately 30 - 50 µm in diameter.

components.data: Dilute the enzyme/protoplast solution with an equal volume of W5 solution.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Dilute the enzyme/protoplast solution with an equal volume of W5 solution.

components.data: Resuspend protoplasts
components.name: Section

components.data: Resuspend protoplasts
components.name: Section

components.data:
Rinse 2 clean layers of miracloth in W5.

 

Filter the enzyme solution containing the protoplasts with these layers of miracloth.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Rinse 2 clean layers of miracloth in W5.

 

Filter the enzyme solution containing the protoplasts with these layers of miracloth.

components.data: Resuspend protoplasts
components.name: Section

components.data:
Centrifuge the flow-through at 150 g/rcf for 2 minutes (brake ON/hard stop) in a 30ml-round-bottom glass centrifuge tube.

 

Remove as much supernatant as possible and re-suspend protoplasts by gentle swirling.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Centrifuge the flow-through at 150 g/rcf for 2 minutes (brake ON/hard stop) in a 30ml-round-bottom glass centrifuge tube.

 

Remove as much supernatant as possible and re-suspend protoplasts by gentle swirling.

components.data: Use haemocytometer to calculate the concentration of protoplasts.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Use haemocytometer to calculate the concentration of protoplasts.

components.data: Resuspend protoplasts
components.name: Section

components.data: Re-suspend in W5 solution to a concentration of 2x105/mL.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Re-suspend in W5 solution to a concentration of 2x105/mL.

components.data: Resuspend protoplasts
components.name: Section

components.data: Rest protoplasts on ice for at least 30 minutes. Protoplasts should begin to settle to the bottom of the tube by gravity. Remove as much W5 solution as possible without touching the pellet. Re-suspend at 2x105/mL in MMG solution kept at room temperature (will need to do another count using haemocytometer before resuspension).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Rest protoplasts on ice for at least 30 minutes. Protoplasts should begin to settle to the bottom of the tube by gravity. Remove as much W5 solution as possible without touching the pellet. Re-suspend at 2x105/mL in MMG solution kept at room temperature (will need to do another count using haemocytometer before resuspension).
